pr_title: DDF-5649 G-6176 Add interface to filter warnings

timeline.message:
DDF-5649 G-6176 Add interface to filter warnings

In response to a malfunction of a query which the user runs, the user
would like a message which describes or explains the malfunction. This
commit provides infrastructure which supports this desire in that it:

 - enables that a SourceResponse contain the ProcessingDetails which a
   Source generates via a query

 - ensures that the implementations of SourceResponse not return null
   from getProcessingDetails(), in accordance with the dictate of the
   Javadoc of SourceResponse.getProcessingDetails()

 - adds an interface—SourceWarningsFilter—which allows that a Source
   which implements it filter() the warnings of the ProcessingDetails of
   the SourceResponse which it receives back from a query and thereby
   produce a Set which contains, exclusively, each warning of the
   ProcessingDetails which describes or explains a malfunction which
   occurred in the execution of the query

 - refactors some of the code which relates to the changes listed above

timeline.bodyText: ❓ Do these lines conform to our formatter? If not, we need to format. If so, we should update the formatter. This can make it difficult debugging the result of the condition because there's a chance the stack context gets lost immediately. You don't want the stack to immediately change in the debugger window when this == o evals to true, you'd want an extra frame to verify that flow without losing your stack.
timeline.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: These lines conform to our formatter, so do with that information what you will. I'll assuage your concerns about these lines and the others like them with an appropriate refactor, though.
replies.author: kentmorrissey

While this interface is functional and tested, it may change or be + * removed in a future version of the library. + */ +public interface SourceWarningsFilter { + + /** + * Get the identifier of this {@code SourceWarningsFilter} + * + * @return either the identifier or, if this {@code SourceWarningsFilter} has no identifier, the + * empty {@link String} + */ + String getId(); + + /** + * Determine whether this {@code SourceWarningsFilter} can correctly filter out unreadable or + * useless {@code warnings} contained in the {@link ProcessingDetails} passed to it. timeline.bodyText: ❓ Are we filtering or determining? What happens if this SourceWarningsFilter can't correctly filter? Does it throw an exception? Should we also have a canFilter function as well? Or is this documentation irrelevant because all SourceWarningsFilters can actually filter any ProcessingDetails object it comes across?
timeline.author: Lambeaux

See the + * GNU Lesser General Public License for more details. A copy of the GNU Lesser General Public + * License is distributed along with this program and can be found at + * . + */ +package ddf.catalog.security; + +import ddf.catalog.operation.ProcessingDetails; +import java.util.Set; + +/** + * This code is experimental. While this interface is functional and tested, it may change or be + * removed in a future version of the library. + */ +public interface SourceWarningsFilter { + + /** + * Get the identifier of this {@code SourceWarningsFilter} + * + * @return either the identifier or, if this {@code SourceWarningsFilter} has no identifier, the + * empty {@link String} + */ + String getId(); + + /** + * Determine whether this {@code SourceWarningsFilter} can correctly filter out unreadable or + * useless {@code warnings} contained in the {@link ProcessingDetails} passed to it. If it can, so + * filter the {@link ProcessingDetails}'s {@code warnings} and create a {@link Set} composed + * exclusively of the {@code warnings} which pass through the filter.

replies.bodyText: This ☝️ is probably the most crucial thing that needs resolution.
replies.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: I think we should change getId() to canFilter() and rewrite the Javadoc of this method to specify that no class should filter() until it has determined that it canFilter(). @mojogitoverhere, we sort of talked about this. What do you think?
replies.author: kentmorrissey

replies.bodyText: Alternatively, we could specify in this Javadoc that filter() should return an empty Set if it determines that it can't correctly filter() the ProcessingDetails which it receives as the argument.
replies.author: kentmorrissey

replies.bodyText: ❗️ I wouldn't return an empty set if we can't correctly filter. Then how would we tell the difference between an inability to filter and a successful filter that yields empty?
replies.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText:
Using canFilter() would make the whole SourceWarningsFilter plugin system more generic. Right now, each SourceWarningsFilter is tied to a single source since we only use a filter if its getId() matches the source id of the ProcessingDetails object it is filtering. After talking with @kentmorrissey a while back, I think we agreed that using canFilter() would be more complex and we probably aren't going to need it (YAGNI) so we opted to stick with getId() for now.
To answer your questions @Lambeaux:

Are we filtering or determining?

Filtering

What happens if this SourceWarningsFilter can't correctly filter? Does it throw an exception?

I'm not sure I understand how the filtering could fail. The idea was that we would check if warning string matches some kind of pattern. If it matches, then keep the warning, otherwise filter it out.

Should we also have a canFilter function as well? Or is this documentation irrelevant because all SourceWarningsFilters can actually filter any ProcessingDetails object it comes across?

Like I said above, we thought about using a canFilter() function but thought that added too much overhead. Instead each SourceWarningsFilter is tied directly to a source by its id.
replies.author: mojogitoverhere

replies.bodyText: After talking in person we decided to go with the canFilter() approach. And to clarify the javadoc accordingly.
replies.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: 👎 I personally would not do that. The classes would incur more overhead than they resolve.
replies.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText:
From my understanding If we're using Sonar as part of our Code Quality Policy in DDF this will break the build
https://rules.sonarsource.com/java/RSPEC-107
replies.author: mazarag2

replies.bodyText:
There's a lot about Sonar that is good. But I don't think we fix every finding that gets reported. We're only at six arguments, that's not terrible. If we need to add more, then it might be time to reconsider.
Good candidate for suppression IMHO.
replies.author: Lambeaux

 - adds an interface—SourceWarningsFilter—which allows that a Source

   the SourceResponse which it receives from the execution of a query

   of the ProcessingDetails which describes or explains a malfunction

timeline.bodyText:
I think this method's logic can be shortened. to
return (o!=null && getClass() == o.getClass() && super.equals(o)
This is because line 91 and 92 do the same comparison that is done in this classes super class.
In fact, you could probably omit this method and just rely on the super method (unless you need to know if two compared objects are of the same impl type instead of just the same interface type).
timeline.author: brianfelix

replies.bodyText: @kentmorrissey were these equals() and hashcode() functions generated by IntelliJ?
replies.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: I don't think I should omit this method because the inclusion of this method allows that, where applicable, tests can verify that exceptions and sourceIds match in addition to warnings.
replies.author: kentmorrissey

timeline.author: brianfelix

replies.bodyText: @kentmorrissey were these equals() and hashcode() functions generated by IntelliJ?

timeline.bodyText:
✏️ If you are just checking for equality to null, you can avoid implementing the equals method and replace
processingDetails.equals(null)

with
processingDetals == null

Note that not implementing the equals method is only if you don't need the equals method for other checks of equality.
timeline.author: brianfelix

timeline.bodyText:
Braces should be added to conform to google style as listed on the "Coding Standards" page on confluence. This statement applies to the entire PR.

4.1.1 Braces are used where optional
Braces are used with if, else, for, do and while statements, even when the body is empty or contains only a single statement.
timeline.author: brianfelix

timeline.message:
DDF-5649 G-6176 Add interface to filter warnings

In response to a malfunction of a query which the user runs, the user
would like a message which describes or explains the malfunction so that
the user can more easily resolve the malfunction. This commit supports
the user's aforementioned desire in that it:

 - enables that a SourceResponse contain the ProcessingDetails which a
   Source generates via a query

 - ensures that the implementations of SourceResponse not return null
   from getProcessingDetails(), in accordance with the dictate of the
   Javadoc of SourceResponse.getProcessingDetails()

 - adds an interface—SourceWarningsFilter—which allows that a Source
   which implements it filter the warnings of the ProcessingDetails of
   the SourceResponse which the Source receives from the execution of a
   query and, thereby, produce new ProcessingDetails whose warnings
   contain only each warning of the original ProcessingDetails which
   describes or explains a malfunction which occurred in the execution
   of the query

 - refactors some of the code which relates to the changes listed above

timeline.bodyText: ❓ Why are null semantics leaking into the equals(..) method? Shouldn't the constructor enforce that, worst case, the list of warnings are empty?
timeline.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: Maybe the constructor should enforce that, but it doesn't. Do you recommend that I alter the constructor such that it enforces that its warnings cannot take a null value?
replies.author: kentmorrissey

replies.bodyText: Yes that would be a good improvement. It should not support taking null but, rather, an empty list if necessary. That cleans up your equals method and the associated tests.
replies.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: Do you think that the constructor should throw an Exception when it receives null as an argument, or just set warnings to an empty List in that case?
replies.author: kentmorrissey

replies.bodyText: Definitely throw. Something like notNull(your_object, "this thing can't be null") would work fine.
replies.author: Lambeaux

timeline.bodyText: ❓ You're defining equality as this.warnings being a superset of that.warnings, is that really what you want?
timeline.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: ❗️ Verify this is not a bug.
replies.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: How would it be a bug?
replies.author: kentmorrissey

replies.bodyText: @Lambeaux In the case that this.warnings is a superset of that.warnings, that.warnings.size() will not be equal to this.warnings.size() which will correctly have the method return false.
replies.author: brianfelix

replies.bodyText: Ah! Totally missed that. My eyes focused in on the one-sided contains check. That should be fine 👍
replies.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: Any set is a superset of itself.
replies.author: kentmorrissey

timeline.bodyText: ❓ Can we be consistent with our equals methods? The other object defers to super.equals(..) and this one basically re-implements it.
timeline.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: Which super.equals() does this method basically reimplement?
replies.author: kentmorrissey

timeline.bodyText: ✏️ This is fine, but it hides the fact that all you're really doing is a reference equality comparison. Unless of course this object's inheritance hierarchy changed. Better to be explicit.
timeline.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: So you think I should change line 49 back to if (this == 0)?
replies.author: kentmorrissey

replies.bodyText: Oh I see what you did. You tried to be consistent, per my previous comment, but one of the objects actually needed to reference the parent. Okay this is fine.
replies.author: Lambeaux

timeline.bodyText: ✏️ Same here. It's fine for now. But it adds an unnecessary level of indirection.
timeline.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: These lines call SourceProcessingDetailsImpl's equals(). Do you think that adds an unnecessary level of indirection?
replies.author: kentmorrissey

replies.bodyText: No, you're right. I missed that. 👍
replies.author: Lambeaux

timeline.bodyText: ✏️ Could use Collections.singletonList(...) instead.
timeline.author: Lambeaux
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -82,6 +93,21 @@ public ProcessingDetailsImpl(SourceProcessingDetails details, String sourceId) {
     return warnings;

replies.bodyText: ...instead of to ‍toWarningList()?
replies.author: kentmorrissey

replies.bodyText: Correct. The toWarningList() method is creating a general purpose collection, meant to hold multiple elements, and is mutable. By using Collections.singletonList(list) you are cutting down on code, memory usage, and get immutability for free.
replies.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: It's mutable, but never mutates. Neither ProcessingDetailsImpl nor SourceProcessingDetailsImpl either adds a warning to this.warnings or provides a method to do so. If I use Collections.singletonList() as you suggest, shouldn't I delete toWarningList()?
replies.author: kentmorrissey

replies.bodyText: Yes the idea is that singletonList() replaces toWarningList() and similar cases where a method like that would be needed. But I'm not mandating the change for approval.
replies.author: Lambeaux

replies.bodyText: I know. I just wanted to make sure that I understood your suggestion. I agree with you, so I'll make the change which you suggested in this comment.
replies.author: kentmorrissey
